background:
Chief Justice Roberts
### Chief Justice Roberts:
We will hear argument next in Case 24-304, Laboratory Corporation of
America versus Davis. Mr. Francisco.
### Noel J. Francisco:
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: Two basic principles
resolve this case.
First, a class action is just a tool for aggregating claims.
So, if an individual plainti� doesn't have Article III standing to bring his
own claim, he can't bring it as part of a class either.
That's why Laroe held that an intervenor has to show Article III standing
in order to intervene, and, as Justice Scalia said in Shady Grove, class
actions are just another species of joinder. Second, Rule 23(b)(3)'s
predominance requirement leads to the same result.
If a class is de�ned to include plainti�s without Article III standing and,
as a result, you need thousands of mini-trials to separate the wheat
from the cha�, the Article III issue necessarily swamps any common
ones. This case is a perfect example. Plainti�s who don't want to use
kiosks don't have standing to challenge how kiosks work any more than
a vegan has standing to challenge how a restaurant de�nes a mediumLABORATORY CORPORATION OF AMERICA HOLDINGS, ... https://apps.oyez.org/player/#/roberts13/oral_argument_...
1 of 98 22/08/2025, 00:25
rare steak. As a result, the Court needs to assess whether each of the
8,000 to 112,000 class members actually want to use kiosks, and that
will necessarily swamp any common issues, as the D.C. and First Circuits
correctly held in the Rail Freight and Asacol cases. Plainti�'s only
response is to say that courts should assess the merits �rst and
jurisdiction second.
But that makes no sense. What if they lose on the merits? Either the
unnamed class members are bound by a judgment regardless of
whether the court had Article III jurisdiction over it, or the court has to
determine if it had jurisdiction over each plainti� in the �rst place.
And that's why courts have to address the jurisdiction before the merits,
just like in every other case. Plainti�'s rule, in contrast, assumes either
they win or coerce a settlement, but there's no basis for that "heads I
win, tails you lose" approach to Article III. I welcome your questions.

importantly, that is precisely why the Ninth Circuit resolved the

It issued a judgment.
That judgment went against us.
It had reasoning.

appeal. We're basing this on the May order.
We're not may -- basing it on the August order because you didn't move
to amend. Isn't us looking at the May order -- that's not the operative
language right now. Isn't it an advisory opinion?
### Noel J. Francisco:
Not at all, Your Honor, for a couple of di�erent reasons.
### Justice Sotomayor:
